awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: State Violence and the Struggle for Life
awd_abstract_narration:
This research addresses several significant questions in social science research and political science in particular. First, it brings a political science perspective to the issue of state and intimate violence by providing a detailed analysis of the experiences of women and women-activists from a marginalized group. Second, this research will contest the silences surrounding Black women as key actors for understanding Black Politics. Such silences help to perpetuate everyday assumptions about race, gender, violence and the public/private divide with regards to political thinking, action, and justice. The research will document new trends and demonstrate how, and why, gender and race are pivotal in addressing the issue of state violence.   In particular, this research will broaden categories for data collection for state violence, which can incorporate the importance of understanding how racially marginalized women experience and understand state violence. This work can be a point of reference for creating better international, national, and local responses that hold states and institutions accountable for violence and injustice, which could therefore help to create a more democratic and just society for all. In addition, the results of this study will be shared  with the two organizations with that provide the basis of the fieldwork. In addition, the results of this study can help to address the needs for distributive justice and support for Afro-descendant women as well as for continued research on the topic of gendered anti-blackness and state violence. 

Anti-Black state violence is a pervasive problem throughout the Americas. Emerging scholarship examining the gendered dimensions of this phenomenon revisit the links between anti-Black state violence and violence against women. This body of work draws on the long history of work thought examining the ways that the state infiltrates, violates, and controls black women's intimate spheres of the body, the home, and the family. As such, this project examines the role of intimacy in contemporary manifestations of anti-black violence and Black mobilizations. Drawing on original ethnographic insights from Afro-Brazilian and Afro-Colombian women, this dissertation posits three arguments. First, state violence invades intimate spaces: the home and relationships--and is, therefore, a form of intimate violence. Second, when Black women narrate these acts of violence, they develop a new way of understanding the state: they show how the state is [re]constituted by means of intimate violations. Thus while Black women's accounts unveil the ways in which state violence is intimate, their voices and organizing also demonstrate how these spaces are important sites for creating new forms of knowledge and resistance. Third, Black women's experiences with anti-black violence are often articulated and interpreted through a collective lens, whereby Black women not only use a language of intimacy to describe experiences with state violence, but also [re]claim domains of the intimate to empower themselves, their families, and their communities. these result in a politic of collective intimacy, which provides a way to resist state violence, hold community and family members accountable, and envision justice beyond the state.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
During the grant period, I conducted 12 semi-structured and oral history Interviews, 3 focus group workshops, and daily participatory observations. My specific objectives for conducting research were to center the leadership and intellectual contributions of Afro-Colombian and Afro-Brazilian women organizers and their use of a lexicon and practice of intimacy. In this way, the project contributes to literature demonstrating that the politics of state violence are profoundly gendered in sexualized in ways that challenge analyses privileging race and/or class. The second objective of this project is to construct a grounded, community-based, global-intimate theory the importance of territorial politics of the politics of intimacy, care, and black mothering. The initial analysis of ethnographic notes and interviews has led me to consider the following possible directions for theoretical development in her dissertation:

Documenting sexual and gender based violence against black women: The work of the documenters is an extreme form of self love that I would like to explore more. Black women in Northern Cauca organized to get women, families, and generation element in the peace accords and have organized to develop a methodology rooted in their own experiences with violence but most importantly their experiences as Black women. I think that this is a really amazing example of intersectional organizing, but I am finding that the way that they articulate their experiences—and demand their experiences to be written, documented, recorded, understood— is often at odds with the requirements and demands of the state (no surprise). But what I finds really interesting is how they to a certain extent are demanding that the state’s perception of their experiences change. For example, in documenting cases, there is a report being written about Black women’s experiences but its limited to the armed conflict. As many of the women have stated and continue to state in interviews and meetings is that this is not a phenomenon that began and ended in 1964 and in 2016 with the signing of the peace accords. It is related to development plans that have displaced black women and communities form territories, it is related to the presence of paramilitary groups that intimidate black women for organizing around collective land rights and women’s rights, its related to the mining and the mercury contamination etc. So there is understandably frustration with the picture the government is trying to draw and their complex, everyday lives. But the way that they go about the work, of talking/interviewing the women, and how they talk about this experience is really powerful. From the stories, the gestures, the tears, the late nights, you see this is really an act of great love both for themselves and the women whose cases they document.

Mobilizing and institutionalizing intersectionality: I have been working on a few projects (still aligned with the dissertation) about development plans here in Colombia (PDET), the ethnic chapter of a Gender Public Policy Agenda, and the implementation of the peace accords. Broadly speaking, these three projects are comparing what grassroots organizers have proposed in these three different settings and what the government has taken from the proposed agreements. One of the interesting (maybe) elements that I am finding through this process is that the agreements proposed at the community level are intersectional in a way that could potentially challenge a number of logics fundamental to the nation-state (e.g. capitalist accumulation, anti-blackness, patriarchy, white supremacy, local authority, such as the Maroon Guard), yet the ones that the national government actually implemented are intersectional, but not in the sense of calling into question these logics. They’re intersectional in the sense that race/ethnicity, gender, space (e.g. territoriality) are mentioned. So on the surface the final policies look like a win for local organizers and the advancement of ethno-racial- gender based policies and frameworks. Yet, some of the analyses that have come from workshops have demonstrated that the policies that the government has adopted a) don’t dismantle the racial order 2) place black communities, and black women in particular, in situations of dependency, precarity, and vulnerability.

Results from this research detail the impacts of different forms of gender- based violence, from an ethno-racial perspective— that is occurring within contexts of armed conflict and urban violence. Such a perspective can help to advance an intersectional understanding of human rights abuses and the study of human rights and public policy more broadly. This research describes the individual and collective consequences of urban violence and armed conflict from an intersectional (race/gender/space) lens, as well as discuss Afro- descendant women’s everyday forms of resistance and healing to redress harm that has been caused. This research can impact policies that can broaden categories for data collection for urban violence and armed conflict, which can incorporate the importance of understanding how racially marginalized women understand and politicize the violence they have experienced.
